651336144.name: Climb to the Pyramid But Not Easy
651336144.author: a TripAdvisor user
651336144.reviewBody: This is supposed to be the easier way to the Pyramid This is not an easy climb great views but be prepared with water, sunscreen, snack, and good hiking shoes, bug spray would also help. The vista is pretty as you look down at the pyramid and the town. There are no vendors and you can go this way and head down to town the other way if you go to the Pyramid. If you are not confident on steep climbs with no guard rails this is not for you.

650076997.name: Go early
650076997.author: a TripAdvisor user
650076997.reviewBody: This is a short, but very steep, hike up a trail that is mostly uneven rocks, so wear appropriate clothing and shoes, and take plenty of water. Go early to get to the top before the mid-day heat and the crowds. If the archaeological site opens at 9, you can start the trek at 8:15 or so to reach the gate around opening time. All in all, this was a great morning adventure with excellent views at the top! For reference, I am a fairly strong hiker and was carrying my 20-month-old son. It took me an hour to get to the top.

624793348.name: Pueblo Magico, really magic
624793348.author: a TripAdvisor user
624793348.reviewBody: Nature all over the place. Challenge to climb to the top, but when you reach the Pyramid all you effort become worth. Take some time to see town views and rest in any food place, handmade tortillas and everything else from mexican ethnic cuisine. Don\'t forget to have water with you.

597972183.name: Gorgeous view, not for the faint of heart!
597972183.author: a TripAdvisor user
597972183.reviewBody: Gorgeous view from up top. The ruin itself maybe not worth the climb up the endless staircase, but the view of the town certainly is. Sitting up there, legs dangling off the rock wall, is quite an experience.

560927139.name: Challenging experience but worth every step
560927139.author: a TripAdvisor user
560927139.reviewBody:
We climb the Tepozteco to get to pyramid at the top of the mountain.
We started at 10:30 am but I suggest that start early, 8:00 am is my suggestion.
The climbing is through a path of rocks and sometimes stairs carved on stone, but all the time is way up.
For a person that runs 5 km and make exercise on a regular basis (at least 4 times per week) to total time from the bottom to the top takes 25 minutes, for a sedentary person it could take 1 hour to get to the pyramid.
Pets are not allowed so please don’t take your dogs, it gets crowded the dogs feel nervous and  some of them couldn’t make it, so you have to carry them on arms.
Take water and candies for energy, as well as shoes with thick soles, because of the rocky surface, if you go with flats or tennis shoes for walk, your feet will hurt, absolutely no heels or fancy shoes.
Regarding small children, do not take small children under 11 or 12 years old, unless these kids run short runs or practice sports like football or something like that, otherwise you will have to carry them on your back or arms.
Also senior persons should be aware of the effort, there is no toilets along the route so be prepare for that.
Finally, do not take strollers, there is no room and no path for them, remember the road is up and high, rocky, no flat surface, and irregular sharp rocks.
But at the top you will find a gorgeous view.
Enjoy the trip

551568023.name: STUNNING ~ You must go!!
551568023.author: a TripAdvisor user
551568023.reviewBody: A beautiful place - but a lot of walking....lol!! Prepare yourself! Prepare a back`pack for the afternoon....snacks, protein bars and lots of water! We spent about 6 hours hiking and about 300 + pictures! LOl. ENJOY!!

539545463.name: Beautiful Nature
539545463.author: a TripAdvisor user
539545463.reviewBody: Although the steep hike to Tepozteco is temporarily closed due to the earthquake, there are other places in the area you can hike.  Our friend, who is a local, took us hiking on the other side of the Tepozteco pyramid.  The flowers, birds and other bits of nature were marvelous.  It\'s probably best to hire a guide, though.

529002380.name: Great Views, Worth the Hike
529002380.author: a TripAdvisor user
529002380.reviewBody: Easily accessible from town, it\'s 2.5 km pretty much straight up the stairs and rocks.  It\'s kind of tiring but well worth the exertion for the views of the area and town below.  There are several rest areas off to the side of the trail to rest and drink wate.

483988935.name: Amazing Pyramid at top of a mountain
483988935.author: a TripAdvisor user
483988935.reviewBody:
Sure, it makes people wonder what this pyramid is all about...... I think it is a very interesting place to visit, a ceremony center on top of huge rock formation. Going up you can see amazing views of all the city Tepoztlan. An amazing nature's work of art. (the mountains, not the pyramis which was built by tepoztecos).

YET, the Parque Nacional needs to do more for the tourists to be able to get up there and down safely. There are steps the first 20 minutes of the walk up the mountain, then suddenly they disappear and become climbing rocks (which are perfect for people who are active and do sports, not for older people, younger children, or people with not a good physical condition.  No warning signs about all this either.
Rocks are easy to climb at first, then they get a bit trickier. Now, going down is a different story. Rocks are smooth and slippery.  Careful when it's raining or you feel it will rain!!!

The pyramid is not that guarded, people are allowed to climb up, which is fun yet it should be protected really.

651341805.name: Worth A Look
651341805.author: a TripAdvisor user
651341805.reviewBody: There are vendors in temporary stalls on the street and then a more permanent arrangement with a food type of court.  Also along one side of the street are some shops that are worth a look. From junk to treasures, The old man doing art on tree barks, great shawls and vests and sweaters,You can go and find nothing or lots of interesting pieces.It is hit or miss. It can be pretty crowded in the street and around some of the vendors. The stores are little more upscale and more expensive but if you are looking for woven pieces it does give you an idea of comparative prices.

646128816.name: Culture
646128816.author: a TripAdvisor user
646128816.reviewBody: Great place to visit if you want the tradition Mexican feeling. Food stands are a must. The shows the local bands put are amazing.

626807781.name: From high crafts to airport junk.
626807781.author: a TripAdvisor user
626807781.reviewBody: Regular weekend visits to Tepotzlan for the Market. Lots of very inexpensive stalls selling great stuff in the $10.00 range for friends and family. Intersting jewelry, wooden items, etc. Temporary stalls up and down the main street. For fine crafts try the shops on the main street and the side streets behind the cathedral. My favorite is Santa Fe. for flowing silk pieces and for very fine and reasonable priced sculpture and paintings. Great items range from $20 to $1000. great service. The place is a zoo so be prepared for some jostling and crowds. Parking is readily available in the centere of the city, so don\'t get nervous and park far away. When the heat gets you get a cone from Tepotznieves. Tropical flavors mmm. A visit to the Dominican ex-convento, monastary will give you the best views of the mountains for photos. You\'ll probably catch a wedding or baptism.

594282330.name: Great place to eat or get fruit
594282330.author: a TripAdvisor user
594282330.reviewBody:
I ate in the market every night as I usually do in any Mexican Town.Great choices especially the pre hispanic options. Also I dont like meat much so the way they make up veggies with sauce for some great tacos was excellent. if you like meat well you will like those options also. 

Pick up some good fruit also.
I did not check out much the souvenir stuff but looks like they have a good selection.Great to just stroll around this market and the main square. 

Check out the pics on this listing for a good idea of what to expect.

588693286.name: Oh my heart
588693286.author: a TripAdvisor user
588693286.reviewBody: My heart pretty much exploded.\nSomething about this little pueblito town captured my heart ! I purchased mostly fabric goods ... clothing, blankets, and wraps which I believe to be at a cheap price for the quality. I would love to come back and stay here for a nice long while ...

588539583.name: Fantastic market with food, souvenirs, and pretty much everything you could need.
588539583.author: a TripAdvisor user
588539583.reviewBody: Had A great time wandering the streets of the weekend market all day long. Go deep into the center to find the best Mexican food.  I\'d recommend eating a little bit from lots of different vendors. Haggling is welcome, local crafts are very reasonable and high quality. We got gems from the region, amber, wooden cooking utensils, and more. Do not miss it if you are visiting the town!

546848541.name: Be surprised what you find here!
546848541.author: a TripAdvisor user
546848541.reviewBody: It\'s exciting to walk through this mercado which has a lot to offer. From food to clothes to gift items it\'s endless. A lot of interesting handicrafts you\'ll find here which is well worth the look. Highly recommend when you\'re in Tepoztlan.

520779565.name: A Shopping experience in a beautiful setting
520779565.author: a TripAdvisor user
520779565.reviewBody: A beautiful shopping experience offers some traditional Mexican handicrafts but also some of the more unique and artistic items. Some boutiques take credit cards but most are cash only. Arrive at the beginning of the market and walk down as driving in this area is congested.

487518749.name: This market is in the middle of everything!
487518749.author: a TripAdvisor user
487518749.reviewBody:
I have been coming here for years! So, tip number one: bring cash, tip number two: show up after 11am.

Having said this, you can find quite a variety of crafts and hand-made products.  The best avocado you will find in town and lovely and unique stuff for you to take back home.

Avoid eating inside the Market, there is no cleanliness there at all and you could get seriously poisoned (I have...) there are hundres of spots to eat ALL AROUND the market, just go there to shop and have some fun.

476610281.name: Very interesting and quaint town.
476610281.author: a TripAdvisor user
476610281.reviewBody: There are ruins you ca hike to...but it takes about an hour uphill and another hour down hill.. So plan accordingly.  The church in town is quite quaint. I arrived Holy Thursday and the different alter decorations were impressive with hand cut paper and fruits.  The entrance of the church decorated by hand in different grains is also equally impressive.  There is a vast market where you can get all kinds of hand I crafts and artisanal pottery.  I ate at  Los colorines restaurant which had great food.  The open traditional kitchens are also impressive.

476606104.name: Average, worth checking out
476606104.author: a TripAdvisor user
476606104.reviewBody: There\'s a wide variety of products, all sorts of prices and quality, however, do not expect to find much if you arrive early in the day

464117348.name: Take cash, You will need it. Many artesenal products.
464117348.author: a TripAdvisor user
464117348.reviewBody: Shop, gaze bntween 12noon and 2:00pm. Very crowded after 2:00pm. Not to saythat it can\'t be before 2:00pm. Girls check for the manta dresses, Yucatan Linen/Coton, guys the guyaberas. Lots of handcrafts, excellent restaurants.

450565466.name: Visit yesterday
450565466.author: a TripAdvisor user
450565466.reviewBody: A interesting market.  You can get a feel of the local people and what they like et cetera.  I wold recommend it including the food. They have fruits I have never seen ever.

431376371.name: The GPS pinpoint on TripAdvisor app is wrong!
431376371.author: a TripAdvisor user
431376371.reviewBody: Do not use the app to get to the market. It is completely wrong.. Head into Tepoztlan and you\'ll find it easily. The other place is a small town with drunks wandering around at 10am... \ud83d\ude11. The correct place is great where you can find everything from $30 baby pitbulls to beautiful tablecloths!

407093350.name: Great town to kick back and relax
407093350.author: a TripAdvisor user
407093350.reviewBody:
This town is easily accessible by bus -- I came from Cuernavaca and it cost something like $17 pesos, or less than $1USD. The outdoor market gets going at around 10:30 or 11. It is very crowded on the weekend. There are many shops and restaurants lining the streets.

From here you can hike Z.A. El Tepozteco (see reviews).

If you're not much of a shopper, go on the hike and/or visit the churches. I happened to arrive just at the start of a massive Confirmation ceremony, led by the Bishop. He gave an engaging speech and the ceremony was beautiful. (see pics)

I am not big into shopping, but this is where I bought all the presents I was bringing back. In other towns and archeological sites I visited I felt overwhelmed by the people hawking their wares. Here, the salespeople are much more laid back. I rarely haggled over the price because it seemed to me that the prices were fair if not quite low. The only time I asked for a break was when I was buying 3 of the same shirts. 

If you wish to buy "authentic" Mexican items, read the labels. You will find a lot of stuff from India. 

There are many massage places here. My classmates from ASLI language institute in Cuernava all went to different places and everyone said they were clean and relaxing. A 1-hour massage was going for about $400pesos, or $22USD. Seriously, there is no need to haggle and if you can get yourself to Mexico you can give a hefty tip. 

Fantastic ice cream and sorbets -- lots of interesting flavors. In the late afternoons on the weekends you'll find the bars are filling up as people buy Micheladas: beer, lime juice, and assorted sauces, spices, and peppers. I had the best Mojito of my life in Tepotzlán.

402883759.name: Excellent Selection of Souvenirs!
402883759.author: a TripAdvisor user
402883759.reviewBody: Come on a Sunday after 11am for one of the largest markets around Mexico City.  Street after street is covered with tianguis.  The selection of souvenirs is vast and inexpensive.  There are many great restaurants around the Zocalo and plenty of clean WC if you need a bathroom.  I recommend parking in one of the pay lots and walking a few blocks down into the center of town.  Don\'t try to drive to the Zocalo.

397083404.name: Best thing about the town-wish I\'d bought more there
397083404.author: a TripAdvisor user
397083404.reviewBody: Everything about the market was fantastic-and I abhor shopping. Great ice cream (nieves) to be found, alleys wide enough to walk through, clean, and with products that I did not see anywhere else. Only thing is that you might want to make sure the vendors don\'t hand you fake coins when they give you change (ok it happened once and when I pointed it out she laughed, said "how did that happen" and gave me a real coin...), but on the other hand, a fake coin makes a good story, and seriously, it\'s 10 pesos, who cares?

389496049.name: fun and funky town
389496049.author: a TripAdvisor user
389496049.reviewBody: We went on a Sunday, and the market was packed.  Lots of stuff to see, decent prices.  There seemed to be mainly tourists.  Many were hiking to see the pyramid on the mountain.  We were there and saw the parade of "chinelos" masked and dressed people.  Masks were covered in seed beads.  Don\'t miss having an ice cream at Tepoznieves-there are at least 100 flavors, and different kinds of ice cream, like beet, carrot, corn, and many other fruit ice creams, such as mixed flavors.  Wonderful.

352740908.name: As Planned
352740908.author: a TripAdvisor user
352740908.reviewBody:
Having done our research, it was the plan to arrive in Tepoztlan on a Sunday, which just happened to be the first day of their celebration of Carnaval aka Mardi Gras in other areas.  Not only was Revolution de 1910 shut down to vehicle traffic as is typical on a Sunday but also Del Tepozteco and 5 de Mayo with all the assorted booths for Carnaval.  As you will see from our submitted photos, the crowds were somewhat overwhelming but we found the citizens to be polite and granted you your space.  

Since we tend to really shop arts & crafts most places we visit in Mexico, we were slightly disappointed but did find a couple of nicely done embroidered items and some woven straw items that were nice.  

The parade and dance of the Chinelos was something we very much looked forward to.  In asking around, we were told that the parade on Monday was to start at 4pm and our plan was to arrive at 3:30pm to secure a place on one of the restaurant second floor terraces for a clear spot to shoot video and regular photos.  Arrived at 3:20pm only to find we were at the rear of the parade.  What the heck - nothing starts early in Mexico!  So we sprinted down the streets, sidewalks, alleys etc to get to the front.  Sacrificed a clear view of the planned dancing on the zocalo (plaza) to get photos of the parade.  An experience of a lifetime and we are so glad it worked out this way!

351957298.name: On the Trail of Los Chinelos
351957298.author: a TripAdvisor user
351957298.reviewBody:
Having been overcome by island fever,  Sandra and I are spending this week in Mexico.  In this instance, the trip is centered around a certain event, the four or five days preceding lent, known through much of the world with a Roman Catholic influence as carnaval.   

    Back in the Land of Bobby Jindal, carnaval is known as Mardi Gras.   On both the Pacific and Gulf coasts of Mexico,  most remarkably Mazatlan and Veracruz, it bears a striking resemblance to the famous carnaval of Rio de Janiero.  Or so we are told.

 In the Mexican highlands, there is a different tradition.  Dating back 200 years, to a time when the blancos held the high hand on most of the indigenous population, some of the uppity Indians in Xochimilco took advantage of a loosening of class differences associated with carnaval.  They wore masks and poked fun at their European masters.  Over the subsequent centuries, this parody has been refined, especially in the state of Morelos, south of Mexico City, to the carnaval of the Chinelos. 

     The word chinelos is derived from a nauhatl word meaning disguise. (Nauhatl is the language of the Aztecs, which is taught and spoken among their descendents.)   There are perhaps five pueblos in Morelos  where the village revs up for carnaval with the chinelos being the focal point of the event.  Latter day Chinelos have a stylized costume comprised of a robe and a mask that imitates the European landowners of the 17th Century.   Apparently these guys wore colorful capes, pointy beards and tall hats in the shape of an inverted cone.

     Being a literary fellow, my preparation began with a book, specifically the Lonely Planet guide to Mexico City, which includes outlying communities such as Cuernavaca and Tepoztlan.   Published in 2008, each year it becomes a bit more out of date.  In this instance, the book suggested that the Chinelos of the outlying communities made their way into Cuernavaca during the week of carnaval, thus sparing the less adventurous traveler the trouble of going to the small, primitive villages. 

   Before accepting this premise, I attempted to verify the information.  If I truly spoke  Spanish  and was
Our new friends, Daira, Samara and Japhet
 willing and able to call Mexico, I might have phoned the chamber of commerce in Cuernavaca, assuming that such exists.  As a substitute, I attempted to phone the Holiday Inn Cuernavaca using a number that I found on line.  I suspected that the guy who answered the phone at that Americanized hotel would speak English better than I spoke Spanish.  What I got was a central Holiday Inn number.  A man with a German accent was unable to connect me to the hotel, but put me on hold while he called the hotel in central Mexico and posed my question:  Does the Carnival occur in Cuernavaca and are the carnaval activities close to the hotel?  

   After a modest hold, he returned to say that the person at the Mexican hotel said that carnaval did take place in Cuernavaca, but the activities were not walking distance to the Holiday Inn.  However, the hotel would provide transportation. He went on to say that he couldn’t understand the concierge in Cuernavaca very well, as he spoke with a Spanish accent.

     “Where are you located?”  I queried.  To which he replied, “I am in Delhi, sir.”

    So at this point we had information obtained by an Indian (spots not feathers) who was taught English by someone from Germany, communicating with a man in central Mexico who might not speak English very well at all.  And most definitely not with a Hindu accent. Perfect.

   Well, the rest is history and a couple days ago we ended up at a really nice little hotel in the historic center of Cuernavaca.  By this time we had ascertained that if carnaval was ever celebrated in Cuernavaca, that was not currently the case.  Not even to the smallest degree.  To see the Chinelos, we would have to travel to Tepoztlan, about twenty kilometros from Cuernavaca.

    On our first day here in the City of Flowers, we visited the Museo Brady.  Robert Brady was an American artist of some considerable means.  He settled in Cuernavaca in a large home that backs on to the catedral.  He then proceeded to paint the rooms in bright colors  and fill them with art which he collected while traveling the world.  Hence, this large home has been converted into a delightfully eclectic museum.  The ante room to the master suite is the Crucifix Room, the guest bedroom is the Oriental Room., there is green bathroom full of ceramic frogs.  It goes on and on.

     While at the Brady Museum, we met two people that provided further information about the carnaval in Tepotzlan.  The first was Sergio, a long haired artistic type who was the only person employed by the Brady Museum who spoke a word of English.  Although Sergio had never been to Tepoztlan to see the carnaval (it just didn’t interest him) he had some useful insights.  It was his impression that the carnaval would be preceded by a mass which would end at 4 PM.  Following the religious ceremony, the Indios would pour forth from the church and head to the carnaval.  If this were true, we wouldn’t need to arrive before three, with the intent of doing some sight seeing and shopping prior to the appearance of the Chinelos.

    A short while later, Sandra cornered two charming girls for a photograph in the Oriental Room.  Their father was pleased to have them talk with us as they were learning English.   At the end of our museum tour we joined  Daria and Samara at a table in Sr. Brady’s courtyard.  The girls, remarkably poised at 7 and 9, study music, piano and flute respectively,  in addition to English and they clearly enjoyed taking pictures.  Their father, Japhet, named after Noah’s son, was well spoken and exceedingly friendly.  Although he had been to Tepoztlan, he chose not to go to the carnaval because of the associated drunken, rowdy behavior. He agreed that this was most likely to occur later in the evening.

     In the process of settling in to our hotel, the Villa Bonito les Terasses, we met Mario, the owner and manager.  Born in Colombia, he grew up in San Francisco and Orlando.  He agreed that arriving in Tepoztlan later in the afternoon would be a good plan.  Further, he offered to drive us there and pick us up for 500 pesos.  This may sound like a lot of money, but the current exchange rate at MEX was 17.15 per USD.  One does not need to be especially skilled at arithmetic to deduce that this is less that $30.  To have this service provided by a dependable friend was almost too good to be true.  Furthermore, although he had not been to the carnaval, he was fairly certain that the proceedings would be quite safe and there was little likelihood of violence of any kind.

   Yesterday at 2 PM we took off with Mario driving us in his comfortable Nissan Pathfinder.  By 2:40 we were in Tepoztlan, Mario driving the back streets to provide us with the best view of the piramide.  This particular piramide is about 1,000 feet up on the cliffs.  Mario invited us to wonder how the Aztecs, or more likely their minions, got the stones all the way up to the top of the mountain.  Nobody knows.

   He dropped us off with intent of seeing us back at the entrance to the village at 7 PM.  Before starting our site seeing, we stepped into a tiny restaurant where the hostess/ chef served quessadillas for 15 pesos.  We ordered two, but before she could get them out of the pan, we heard a brass band.  We ran out into the street to see a band warming up a block up hill and a family preparing their chinelo costumes.

   As the father donned his mask, his lovely wife was dressing their toddler.  At first the youngster didn't like it, throwing off the headgear, but mama outlasted him.  As the band approached, father and son took their place behind.  Chinelos began appearing in the street.  Soon there were twenty or so behind the band, with young men holding banners leading the way.

   At this point Sandra was befriended by a gentleman who insisted on pouring her a tequila and sprite while exhorting the joy of carnaval and los chinelos.  When it became apparent that she was associated with a certain hombre, he had his assistant pour me a tequila, as well.  We put our arms around each other and shouted,"Amigos!" while the redoubtable SKG took a photo from a safe distance.  No fondling these love handles tonight, bucko.     

    Sipping on our ersatz margaritas, we walked up the street with the band and the chinelos, which every now and then absorbed a new comrade.  There were thirty or forty chinelos in front of us and then suddenly there were none.  We looked around and listened, finally hearing some band music coming from the far side of a midway.  Walking through, we came to a balcony overlooking the zocalo.  Below were gathered between 150 and 200 chinelos and four brass bands.

    Before embarking on our journey, I had found a youtube video of the chinelos in Tepoztlan.  it showed roughly two dozen men and one child dancing a shuffling step under an awning on a dusty street.  Nothing had prepared me for this spectacle.  While the brass bands played their dancing song over and over, the chinelos hopped, shuffled and twirled.   The entire zocalo was full of them.

     Clearly the town has grown.  Our source in the pulqueria said that there are now 20,000 potential chilenos living in the puebla magica of Tepoztlan.  Its not clear if you need to be invited to be a chileno.  I doubt that just anyone can whip up a costume and join in uninvited.  It was clear from the divisions and the bands that there were four groups, perhaps representing four parishes.  And no parish was to be outdone by the other, either in noise of their band, twirling and jiving or, especially, endurance. 

   We made our way down and took  a bunch of photos.  One might have thought that the music would stop and the party would become less organized.  But it did not.  A band might stop for a minute, but begin again

 shortly, and the chinelos danced and danced.  After about fifteen minutes,  Sandra and I took a break.  On the opposite side of the zocalo stands the catedral in a large wooded complex.  the church was not open, but the famous sign depicting the Carnaval de Teopztlan surmounted the cathedral gate.  This sign is made of attached seeds and is re-created with fresh seeds each year.  We rested, photographed the festival gate and then rejoined the dancing, which had gone on unabated.  We met an older gentleman, just donning his chinelo costume.  In by the dancing, I photographed a chinelo who had dropped out, albeit after half an hour of non-stop dancing, to share a few frosties with his friends.  

   After about forty minutes, the ropes were let down and we were permitted to enter and dance with the chinelos.  We danced for a while, took some more pictures and retired back up onto the main street.  Food booths, novelties and midway games lined the street for its entire length.  It was barely less noisy than the zocalo.  Even some of the chinelos had had enough; we saw a few walking the street, hat and mask in hand.

    Deciding that we had accomplished our goal, at a little after five we called Mario, who said he would pick us up in an hour.  Just as we were wondering where we might go for that period, a young man offered us a sample of pulque.  It was delicious, so we repaired into the pulqueria where we purchased a half liter of the pinon pulque.  It tasted vaguely of strawberries,  Made from agave and only slightly alcoholic, it was delicious.  and the peaceful pulqeria was the perfect spot to decompress after our dance with the chinelos.

   On the practical side:

1.  the residential town is greatly removed from the lower town where the festival is held.  If you like to sleep at night, you might want to stay above the lower town.
2. The shops are largely taken over by the countless carnaval booths.  These extended about half a kilometer, most of the lenght of the main street.
3.  We were lucky to have a dedicated ride form a responsible friend.  And we arrived at 3 PM and left before dark.  Food for thought...this is rural Mexico, after all.

344584580.name: good to see :)
344584580.author: a TripAdvisor user
344584580.reviewBody: I bought a hat and some traditional snacks. it was interesting to look around. must visit.\nIf it is nearby, I want to go again

334703856.name: Great market
334703856.author: a TripAdvisor user
334703856.reviewBody: Quaint town, and this was a very typical charming market. Lots of fabulous produce, gift wear, wooden bowls, etc. we enjoyed every visit to the market and prices were great

319347836.name: Un Poco de Todo, incl. India
319347836.author: a TripAdvisor user
319347836.reviewBody: Over the years the weekend market has added many items from India & China. Sadly, not everything is Mexican anymore. But it\'s still fun. Most visitors are from Mexico City.

303047396.name: One of the few and still remaining real craftman market in Morelos
303047396.author: a TripAdvisor user
303047396.reviewBody: You will be gladly surprised to find here a colorful array of options. Many real and original locally created crafts are available; many real and important artists have started here. \nYou will find it filled with Chinese trinkets as well, so look carefully what you are acquiring. Do go inside the stores, or the market you will find great surprises there too.\n

287030832.name: Tepoztlan. Pueblo M\u00e1gico
287030832.author: a TripAdvisor user
287030832.reviewBody: Tepoztl\u00e1n, Morelos is a town considered as Magical Town. It is full of interesting places: museums, churches, old houses (from 16th to 20th Centuries). An important attraction is the market. You can find there several kinds of handkrafts as typical clothes made out of cotton and linen, ceramic, wood, glass. You can also find typical food as tacos, quesadillas, sopes at a very low Price and excellent flavor.

248476713.name: Tepoztl\u00e1n arts & crafts market
248476713.author: a TripAdvisor user
248476713.reviewBody: Located in the zocalo, there are a number of permanent booths here open year round. On weekdays only about one third will be open. Saturday and Sundays are market days and then it becomes a madhouse. In addition to every booth in the market opening, all the stores around the zocalo open and a huge variety of street booths open up. One of the better artisan markets in the region.

635476896.name: A Gem in Tepoztlan
635476896.author: a TripAdvisor user
635476896.reviewBody:
When I first visited Lagartija Club Mezcal a few years ago, I knew next to nothing about this wonderful beverage.  But Marco, the co owner along with his wife, Adelfa, spent well over an hour teaching me about mezcal.  He let us taste several of his own mezcals, explaining about the different agaves and how they are processed.

We have just spent five wonderful days in the Pueblo Magico of Tepoztlan and every evening was spent at Lagartija, sampling many different mezcals.  They are available for purchase and we have brought home several.  

If you are a fan of mezcal, or are just curious and want to learn, stop by this wonderful place.

address.streetAddress: Isabel La Catolica 13 Barrio San Miguel, Local B

582861621.name: The best mezcal
582861621.author: a TripAdvisor user
582861621.reviewBody: OMG! So good, I love it!!\ud83d\ude0d Was visiting form ATL and I tried it and I bought some to bring home!! Amazing Smoth taste, got to try it!!

address.streetAddress: Isabel La Catolica 13 Barrio San Miguel, Local B

546847619.name: Very Authentic!
546847619.author: a TripAdvisor user
546847619.reviewBody: A lovely store located in the centro of Tepoztlan. They have many authentic items for sale. A lot of good Mexican character! I would highly recommend to visit.

474838453.name: Tibetan bowls for sale in Mexico
474838453.author: a TripAdvisor user
474838453.reviewBody: A tiny store located on the main avenue to the pyramid with Tibetan bowls. They offer many sizes and prices and will give yu information on their therapies and concerts.

329436883.name: Charming place - good ice cream, too!
329436883.author: a TripAdvisor user
329436883.reviewBody:
Heaps of choices here - and sometimes you can guess, but you might want your Spanish dictionary to go through all of them, if you're picky.  

I had a simple cone. The ice cream is quite different from what I'm used to - good, but a bit 'too' different (more grainy and with rather large 'chunks' in it - I had the Cappucino). So unlike others, I wouldn't say it's the best I've ever eaten. You could probably make a brunch or light lunch out of a lot of the 'exotic' special offerings with fruits, though.

The shop itself is quite charming - all bright and beckoning, though you know you're in Mexico when a giant cross is at the entrance, surrounded by colorful drawings and words related to ice cream!

It's straight across from the Cathedral/Museum (on the side street) so quite easy to find.

480023683.name: amazing
480023683.author: a TripAdvisor user
480023683.reviewBody: Given how shabby looking the centro is of this \'pueblo magico,\' you\'re even more amazed and appreciative that this exceptional, and exceptionally designed, jewel exists. Be sure to go to it. There are so many great international cultural activities here on an ongoing basis.

address.streetAddress: Cerrada de Tecuac Esquina San Lorenzo 44 Valle de Atongo

229990646.name: Entretainment in flowers
229990646.author: a TripAdvisor user
229990646.reviewBody: Naturally ny better half chose to spend a Sunday here. Still I truly enjoyed it. The Japanese garden is cool and beautiful. The main gardens are spectacular. The Italian garden has too much cement. The restaurant is very nice, but it only offers a buffet. Admission price is steep by Mexican standards. Go at sunset. Midday is hot.

address.streetAddress: Calle Sor Juana Ines de La Cruz 26 Barrio Santa Cruz

665709909.name: In need of TLC but promising
665709909.author: a TripAdvisor user
665709909.reviewBody:
Located in what was the granary of the Ex Convento de la Natividad, this small but pleasant museum is made up of the archaeological collection of the Tabasco poet Carlos Pellicer donated to the town in 1965. 

Its collection is composed of more than a thousand Mayan archaeological pieces, Totonacas, Mexicas , Teotihuacanas, Zapotecas, Olmecas, of Tlatilco, of the Coast of Colima and of Tepoztlán.  

In this museum are significant pieces of pre-Hispanic cultures, of which a piece of the god Omeotochtli stands out - Tepoztecatl, with the representative figure of "two rabbits", its shrine is located on the top of Tepozteco hill.

Some websites say it is closed but it is not (was closed shortly after the last earthquake).  Only a suggested (but enforced) donation of 15 pesos to come in.  Some pieces have fallen off their stands and cannot be seen clearly.  INAH (National Institute of Anthropology and History in Mexico) hasn’t had the chance to clean up each display after the earthquake but there is still a lot to see.

You can see the Tepozteco ruin from here via a telescope (3 pesos).  

Closed on Mondays.

itemReviewed.name: Museo de Arte Prehispanico Carlos Pellicer

address.streetAddress: Arq. Pablo A. Gonzalez 2 Parte Posterior del Ex Convento

642075118.name: Old building in need of some improvement
642075118.author: a TripAdvisor user
642075118.reviewBody: It seems there are still Government offices existing but it needs urgently a greater fix up to make it look nice again

603973781.name: This is where I go in January to pay my property tax. I live in Tepoztlan.
603973781.author: a TripAdvisor user
603973781.reviewBody: This isn\'t a tourist stop like the monastery or marketplace are. This is a local government office so tourists don\'t visit it...unless they\'re\ndrunk and disorderly and get hauled in!

480381783.name: huge disappointment
480381783.author: a TripAdvisor user
480381783.reviewBody: For some reason, though the surrounding mountains are spectacular, the town center itself is pathetically shabby and rundown. The Palacio Municipal reflects this. They don\'t spend a penny on upkeep, much less improvement.

319403490.name: On the Strolll Through Town...
319403490.author: a TripAdvisor user
319403490.reviewBody: Stop a minute ot two & look at the city municipal building. Not much to see, really, but still worth a quick look.

248472513.name: Tepoztl\u00e1n town hall
248472513.author: a TripAdvisor user
248472513.reviewBody: The municipal palace, or town hall, of Tepoztl\u00e1n on the zocalo. A fairly innocuous building, it has a variety of small exhibits on local history. For example, they currently have a display documenting the history of Emiliano Zapata Salazar.

665595762.name: True center of knowledge exchange and active community work
665595762.author: a TripAdvisor user
665595762.reviewBody:
It’s so close to the market, it’s worth a short detour to explore.  The entrance is free.  Although not all can be seen since the last major earthquake, there is still plenty to enjoy.  For those who keep complaining about the signs and information being only in Spanish, Google Translate is an easy tool to use and you can get the jest of what is being said/described.  I use it all the time even though I speak Spanish, there are always unfamiliar terms I learn along the way.

Built by the local natives from 1555 to 1580, it was adapted from 9th century Spanish architectural traditions.  Simple but elegant.  Solid but without waste.  Staircase also functioning as pulpit.  Cooking or rain water expertly diverted to either the garden or to a public fountain for the populace.  Designed only to meet the basic needs of the friars, unlike the more expansive convents in Spain.  

Built with stone and ‘mud’ (mixture of clay, slaked lime, volcanic sand, and nopal cactus ‘slime’).  Ivory color used in the background to lighten up the space.  The designs you see today are three different layers.  The first layer (mostly the black designs of kings, shields of the Dominican order, and the virgin Maria) was eventually covered with white lime then painted with red flowers or geometrical patterns.  The lime was later removed revealing the black, and a bit faded, patterns we see today.  The designs are of tempera with iron oxide (red) and mineral coal (black).  

No more than 3 or 4 friars ever lived here at one time.  The majesty of this convent was a response to the utopia of the founders who believed it would eventually house many friars in the future.  They taught the doctrine and did literacy work through community work.

Some of the distinguished friars are buried in the hall they call ‘From the Depths’ in Latin ‘De Profundis…’  

Sixteen arches surround the central patio.  They used to have small walls between them to prevent access to the patio.  You can still see the outline of these walls that are no longer there.  The corridors and rooms have vaulted ceilings.  The friars entered the corridors around the patio in a counter-clockwise fashion to face each of the four altars painted at the corners.  

The old orchard has been turned into a secondary school.  The convent was used by the military for a while.  It was turned into a museum in 1935.  The space has a small store and photo gallery.

A religious festival takes place here every September 8th.  It could be an interesting sight…

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

652145993.name: Ex-Convent
652145993.author: a TripAdvisor user
652145993.reviewBody: Definitely worth your time to visit this historical site to better understand the people of this area of Mexico.

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

634790082.name: A space for reflection and resilience in Tepoztlan
634790082.author: a TripAdvisor user
634790082.reviewBody:
If you look up in the small town of Tepoztlan, the tallest built structures you'll see will be the church bell towers connected to the one-time Dominican monastery of La Natividad. Admission is free, though only the ground floors are open to visitors (as of November 2018). This 16th century monastery is a quiet refuge in a quiet town, and a lovely place for a quick visit. 

When you enter down the graveled path to the monastery, you're greeted by a small green space and a lovely view of the monastery and bell towers. Due to the September 2017 earthquake, only the ground floor of the monastery is open to visitors. This includes the cloister and its garden, the book store, and rooms leading from one to the other. Despite the limited viewing area, the monastery is worth a quick visit.

The walls and arches of the serene cloisters are adorned in intricate black and white and rust-colored drawings. The cloister garden is a sunny refuge with orange trees, peace lilies, and a fountain. Adjoining rooms have modest but impressive portraits of friars, and the general aura of the place is peaceful. 

As of November 2018, the monastery also houses an exhibit on the rebuilding of the church, monastery, and town of Tepoztlan after the devastating earthquake of September 2017. The church and monastery are at the heart of the town, with generations being baptized and married there. The stories told of how people from all walks of life came immediately together to help is inspiring, as are seeing pictures of the rebuilding. As of November 2018, re-construction was ongoing. 

Though not a main draw of Tepoztlan, a visit to the monastery is a quietly rewarding experience.

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

634468064.name: Charming
634468064.author: a TripAdvisor user
634468064.reviewBody: The church, the square (with its many handicraft stalls), and the town are all adorable.  Well worth spending some time.

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

598483171.name: Interesting Stop
598483171.author: a TripAdvisor user
598483171.reviewBody: The Exconvent is worth the visit. Only a portion of the lower floor is available for touring due to earthquake damage. However, there was a beautiful exhibit of traditional women\'s clothing from all over Mexico. You will spend a max of 45 minutes here. It\'s a cool stop on the way to the market.

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

594275130.name: Mustsee. first floor open for visit
594275130.author: a TripAdvisor user
594275130.reviewBody:
Glad they had the first floor open. No charge and nice old convent. Great niches and partial original wall paintings uncovered.
It is too bad the second floor remains closed but someone will post here when they get it open.

I understand they just finished the remodel of the second floor when the Sep 19 quake hit. Luckily the building remained standing.

The church suffered some nasty damage to the cupolas also which you can see. 

Thanks Mexico for having these wonderful buildings available to visit. And no charge in this case. And best of luck working towards repairing these treasures in the future.

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

546309246.name: CLOSED due to earthquake!!
546309246.author: a TripAdvisor user
546309246.reviewBody: I toured this ex-convent about 2 years ago, and it was very interesting and worthwhile. We had a guide who explained much of the history. The museum was closed (even though it was the middle of the day--that\'s Mexico for you). We were hoping to go back last month with my parents and get another tour and hopefully see the museum this time. Alas, the earthquake of Sept. 2017!!! The ex-convent and museum are closed until further notice. We couldn\'t see the convent to assess the damage, but the large church, which is connected, is in terrible shape. There were workers on the roof, and the bell towers are being propped up by wooden framework. The church pews are out in the front courtyard for services. It looks like an impossible task. I can\'t imagine this will be re-opened to the public anytime soon. It\'s such a shame that these historic structures are so damaged after 500 years of life.

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

503554328.name: Peace in a convent?
503554328.author: a TripAdvisor user
503554328.reviewBody: Visiting Tepoztl\u00e1n? Well, you must take a look to the Ex-convento. Now its a museum, but duting the week days, nobody visit it. You can feel the peace in your skin, maybe because the freshnes of the place. So quite, a little bit dark and so old. Believe me, you will enjoy it.

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

500448525.name: Wonderful piece of history
500448525.author: a TripAdvisor user
500448525.reviewBody: The church and convent is a must to visit if you are in Tepotzlan. It is in the center of town and is directly connected to the Weekend market, which is also a must to visit. The building is a wonderful example of architecture for the period and the museum that has been created in the old convent is delightful to tour. Try to visit on Saturday or Sunday afternoon or you might walk into a Mass.

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

499222622.name: Tour of the Ex Convent Dominico de la Natividad
499222622.author: a TripAdvisor user
499222622.reviewBody: It was nice, and free... but if you don\'t read or speak Spanish you are doomed. All explanation boards were in Spanish. They explained pretty much everything about the Ex Convent, when was it built, how, etc., etc., We wanted to see some of the cells, but they were not opened to the public. It\'s a pretty place to visit, if you have an hour or two to spare.

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

490981608.name: Kind of creepy, some cool views of the Tepozteco-Do not seat anywhere!
490981608.author: a TripAdvisor user
490981608.reviewBody:
This place is very cool, at times it feels a little haunted, a little dark and solitary. 
The gardens are well kept and on the top floor there are some amazing views of the Tepozteco. Really hated the grid in the middle though. The poor birds get stuck there and die :( 
Not sure if I would like to see that again. I don't know why they don't want the birds around. Also, you are not allowed to seat anywhere and people "working" there ignore you. There is a library AND librarian but library is out of reach for visitors. Just a strange place in general.

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

479684382.name: Beautiful church with typical Easter Holy Week Decorations
479684382.author: a TripAdvisor user
479684382.reviewBody: I was impressed by the entire campus, but the most impressive to me was the church nuestra Senora de la Natividad. It was Easter Holy Week and the decorations of the different alters inside using the typical paper and very humble contributions of fruits and spices was endearing. The entire them of purple for Easter Holy week was well interpreted in each of the decorated alters.  This is very much frequented by the locals and worth a visit. Also note at the entrance to the campus from the market, the decorations in seeds hand placed individually by local artisans

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

476604297.name: Worth checking it out!
476604297.author: a TripAdvisor user
476604297.reviewBody: As the name says, the place used to be a convent so the building is really old and worn out. However, the entrance is free and it helps you understand how the people lived there as it hosts the city\'s museum. Moreover, it has a great view of the mountains and a telescope to see the pyramid.

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

447850818.name: Very interesting place
447850818.author: a TripAdvisor user
447850818.reviewBody: If you love magic and historical places this is a must. It was erected centuries ago and it\'s full of history.

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

418055598.name: A NICE visit in the city
418055598.author: a TripAdvisor user
418055598.reviewBody: The ex convent is no longer used by the church but it is now kept as a beautiful colonial building. Walking distance from the market it is nice to take a stroll in this colonial building that offers a bit of local history.

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

402884722.name: Beautiful!  A must in Tepoztlan!
402884722.author: a TripAdvisor user
402884722.reviewBody: If you are going to Tepoztlan on a Sunday for the Tianguis, this is a worthwhile stop.  Just off the Zocalo, so no extra driving is necessary.  When you enter the grounds the entrance to the Convent is the doors to the left of the sanctuary.  Check out the beautiful wall designs downstairs, but make sure you go upstairs to see the view!  There is a very nice gift shop downstairs as well.

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

401829783.name: Pretty place, but I thought it\u00b4s bigger
401829783.author: a TripAdvisor user
401829783.reviewBody: The convent is a nice place to visit during stay in Tepoztlan, but don\u00b4t plan to spend a long time there. Unless you want to chill out in the atrium outside the convent- it\u00b4s big and not busy with tourists. The entrance is free. \nInside the building there are murals, but not all of them in a good shape. They are pretty interesting though. Unfortunately no descriptions in English, just Spanish. \nIf you were visiting Europe before this place wouldn\u00b4t be anything extraordinary for you.

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

387610306.name: beautiful Soanish conevent now a museum
387610306.author: a TripAdvisor user
387610306.reviewBody: come see some beautiful 156th century architecture and design, founded by the Dominican nuns in the 1500\'s the convent now no longer active serves a restful haven from the nearby hustle of the market and central park.

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

363210720.name: Fun for a brief walk
363210720.author: a TripAdvisor user
363210720.reviewBody: Interesting to see this beautiful old monastery and the remaining art on the walls and ceiling. Worth a walk-through if you have time.

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

352255136.name: This is a definate stop for you while in Tepoztlan!
352255136.author: a TripAdvisor user
352255136.reviewBody:
This is really a very interesting Cathedral in combination with the Convento Dominico de la Natividad.  The best way to enter it is from the market.  

The entrance gate is grand.  The design (check out the photos) is redone every year by people from the market.  The design is done with seeds from different plants.  It looks like a mural, but upon closer examination, you will see what I mean.  Very unusual.  

Once inside the Convento you will find it very well preserved.  The day we were there was with a small group of students from ASLI Spanish Language Institute of Cuernavaca.  We had one of the employees from the school as our guide, so felt like we got some good insight into what we were seeing.  Once you are on the second floor there are some very nice views of the countryside and the mountains.  Even though I have been through a lot of religious sites in Mexico, this one had a unique interest.

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

345481125.name: Great stop in Tepoztlan
345481125.author: a TripAdvisor user
345481125.reviewBody: Definitely worth stopping in, free to visit and is a beautiful facility. Doesn\'t take long to go through the entire building!

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

342817213.name: Beautiful Restoration
342817213.author: a TripAdvisor user
342817213.reviewBody: This former convent has had a restoration of it\'s beautiful wall frescoes and designs. This space is peaceful, graceful and a window into the past world of Mexican religious art.

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

337660301.name: Nice historical site
337660301.author: a TripAdvisor user
337660301.reviewBody: Small but interesting historical place, right in the centre of the town. worth seeing. there is also a bookstore inside the building

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

331418255.name: beautiful colonial building
331418255.author: a TripAdvisor user
331418255.reviewBody: Brief but interesting visit, beautiful colonial building, together with the parish church is beautiful altogethe, as well as to walk around the town. Nice market on Sunday.

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

329073590.name: A large place for 4 monks
329073590.author: a TripAdvisor user
329073590.reviewBody: Curiously this large convent never had more than 4 permanent monks at a time, still it is a large building , with a charming patio , a small interesting museum , a few painted roofs and a nice view towards the mountain. It is worth the visit but does not compete with the major  museums in Mexico .

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

327927964.name: Restful
327927964.author: a TripAdvisor user
327927964.reviewBody: Now a local museum, the Dominican convent of Tepoztlan is a nice example of colonial architecture in central Mexico and a nicely restored one. At noon, the central courtyard is a pool of light. One of the second story areas has some impressive views of the Tepozteco mountain. Reached from Cuernavaca city by inter-city Ometochtli bus (50 min from the base in Mercado Lopez Mateos) or by car (some 30 min).

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

319402964.name: Best of the Missions in the Valley
319402964.author: a TripAdvisor user
319402964.reviewBody: The 16th century monastery is well kept & lightly restored for a beautifully serene effect. Upstairs is a small but interesting town museum, and downstairs a fabulous gift store (in the old refrectory part). Be sure to check out the seed mural at the main entrance, assembled each August by the entire village. Definitely worth the free visit!

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

286964592.name: An Spanish ex convent filled with original wall paintings, a fantastic view
286964592.author: a TripAdvisor user
286964592.reviewBody: you will find in this place an amazing example of the effort the Spaniards had to do in order to build and complete living quarters as much a like as the ones back home, but with an unlimited workforce of people in another culture. This comes into contrast when visiting the nearby archeological sites. The place conserved all its original paintings due to the fact that after an epidemic, all of the walls were plastered with cal to sanitize the atmosphere. A true example of colonization. Do get to the second floor, from there you might be able to see the pyramid base on top of the Tepozteco, and a fantastic view of the valley.

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

272607323.name: A mystic place to visit
272607323.author: a TripAdvisor user
272607323.reviewBody: The convent has been established by the Dominicans in the mid 16th century and is now listed as a Unesco world heritage site. The access is free of charge (which is surprising), and the site is very welle documented (spanish only). The murals are awesome but unfortunately not very well preserved. The view from the first floor mirador is breathtaking. I loved the place and its quietness.

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

269103482.name: Lovely old building, beautiful views
269103482.author: a TripAdvisor user
269103482.reviewBody: It helps if you know what to expect when you go here. It\'s an EX-convento, meaning that it used to be the living quarters of Dominican priests during the 16th and 17th century. Now, it is a historical site. There aren\'t a lot of displays. Don\'t expect it to be filled with things to look at. The attraction is the building itself. There are still some of the old murals on the walls, and you can see how the rooms were laid out, stroll in the garden, look at the gorgeous views of the mountains and countryside from the upper floors. It\'s cool and quiet inside, a nice break when the sun gets too hot out in the streets and you want a break from the noise of the marketplace. The building is quite large and lovely to look at. It has a peaceful atmosphere. If you know anything about the history of colonial Mexico, you\'ll like experiencing this building. Hopefully you can find some information about it online and read about it before you go. Tepoztlan, although a small town, was of strategic importance in the 16th century and it has an interesting history, much of it connected to the church. There is no entry fee. No restaurants inside. But there is a charming small bookstore. The state of Morelos has many ex-conventos in small towns, and it\'s worth doing the entire "ruta de los conventos" if you enjoy history and colonial architecture. Some of them are in remote places so you need a car to go there, but it\'s easy to get to Tepoztlan from Cuernavaca (bus or taxi), and if you go on a Sunday when they have the big market in the street, it\'s a very lively atmosphere.

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

248483571.name: Lovely visit
248483571.author: a TripAdvisor user
248483571.reviewBody: A great place to visit while in Tepoztl\u00e1n. The front entry mural is very cool. The grounds themselves are mediocre. The attached church is still in use and is very nice indeed. The attached convent is very cool. You can admire the architecture, some of the original wall paintings, an art gallery, and the official Tepoztl\u00e1n museum is on the second floor. A great place to get your culture on.

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

246439802.name: One of the best colonial convents near Mexico City
246439802.author: a TripAdvisor user
246439802.reviewBody: It makes a great visit for a sunny afternoon, it has wonderful views of the Tepozteco mountain and naif paitings in its walls. Built by the Dominicans in the XVI c. it has an incredible entrance archway made out of different seeds by local artisant every September. The interior is very interesting both the monastery and the church, do not miss the latrines with funny legends in the walls described in informative panels for your enjoyment.

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

246024328.name: Worth popping in
246024328.author: a TripAdvisor user
246024328.reviewBody: While there are more spectacular, this very old convent and cathedral is impressive. At almost 500 years it has survived a lot and witnessed much.\nNice frescos on the wall and an informative geology and botany overview of the area.\n

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

239153238.name: Very Interesting
239153238.author: a TripAdvisor user
239153238.reviewBody: One of the many ex conventos in this part of Mexico, this is perhaps the best of the bunch.  Beautiful black and white wall paintings, a great view from the upper level and an excellent little museum make this place worth a visit.

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

235354661.name: Peaceful place to visit
235354661.author: a TripAdvisor user
235354661.reviewBody: This was an interesting place to visit. The frescos on the courtyard walls were beautiful.  The church was closed the day we went, but we were told it would be open the next day.  It was worth the walk down the hill to see this.

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

210174294.name: Oldest Spanish building in Mexico
210174294.author: a TripAdvisor user
210174294.reviewBody: Built sometime around 1520 this building has survived a number of earthquakes.  It is attached to a church which was built a number of years later.  The monks that lived here spent a good deal of their time painting frescos and other decorations on the walls and ceilings.  The village was built around this structure so it sits in the center of the town.  It is in surprisinly good condition given its age and being in an earthquake zone.

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

206041951.name: Not much to see, but it\'s worth it
206041951.author: a TripAdvisor user
206041951.reviewBody: There is not much to see in the little ex-convent, but it is worth going.  The murals on the walls are very beautiful and really show the age of the convent.  You can see the library (modern) and even the old bathroom.  The views of the city are spectacular from the convent.

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

203743244.name: An Hour in Tepoztlan
203743244.author: a TripAdvisor user
203743244.reviewBody: The ex-convent and church are in the center square of the town, and it\'s an interesting site to start off your day in Tepoztlan. It takes around an hour to walk through, and the old murals on the walls are absolutely stunning. There are also nice views of the town from the upper level of the ex-convent. When I went in May 2014, there was some artwork on display (not sure if it\'s a permanent exhibit) throughout the ex-convent that didn\'t seem to fit at all with the rest of the structure. It was interesting modern artwork, sure, but didn\'t seem to flow well with the rest of the experience. (See in uploaded pictures). Still, if you are genuinely interested in the history here, this is the place to visit.

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

198317488.name: Don\'t miss this site
198317488.author: a TripAdvisor user
198317488.reviewBody: Fascinating to walk through this former convent and experience the facets of their lives as they lived here. Very interesting historically. Great gift shop at the end.

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

193095645.name: A Small But Very Worthwhile Site
193095645.author: a TripAdvisor user
193095645.reviewBody: The Ex-Convent Dominico de la Natividad In Tepoztlan is located on the church grounds of the largest church located near the farmers and craft market in the center of town. This site is definitely worth a visit if you are in the area. It is very beautiful with archways and decorated halls that are quite unique. There is also a viewing area on the top floor in the rear of the convent that gives you a great vantage point for seeing the pyramid on the mountain top. This location also has a small museum and gift shop as well as a cute courtyard with fountain and fruit trees. I enjoy the serenity of this location and visit as often as I come to Tepoztlan.

itemReviewed.name: Ex Convento Dominico de la Natividad

666504762.name: Takes a lot of effort, but woth it
666504762.author: a TripAdvisor user
666504762.reviewBody:
The centre of Tepoztlan is fairly touristy, but with some beautiful craft work. However this is not the reason you come here - there is an Aztec pyramid on a sheer bluff overlooking the town, and it is well worth the visit. The pyramid itself is not big (you can see it perched on the edge of the bluff from down in the town) but the view from the site is spectacular. You walk down the craft-stall lined street leading out of the zocalo, and you begin the climb. At first it is fairly easy, with stone steps, but this gives way to climbing up over rocks, in parts with little evidence of a formed path. The last part is up steel steps through a narrow chasm (when you come to the steel steps, you know you're almost there - phew!) When you come to the top of the steel steps, you are there. There is a small entrance fee, which you pay as you enter the site. You can walk along the edge of the bluff, and take in the spectacular views of Tepotzlan down below, and the surrounding mountains This is the best place to take photos of the pyramid, off to the right. You can climb to the top of the pyramid, where there are the remains of a temple. It took us about an hour and a half to get up, a little less coming down.

This seems to be a popular visit for locals - we went up on New Year's Eve morning, and were amazed at the number of locals going up, so I would recommend, if you are going up in a weekend or on a public holiday, get there early. Remember to take some water with you, but there are vendors at strategic locations along the track an up at the top.

When you get back down to the street, treat yourself to an ice cream or sorbet from one of the stalls - you will have earned it!

Note - if you have any problems with your knees or ankles, do not attempt this - the middle part particularly is very rocky, uneven and steep.

665750707.name: Does 23-66% grade scare you?
665750707.author: a TripAdvisor user
665750707.reviewBody:
Are you ready to hike terrain from 23% to 66% grade?  If so, this is the hike for you.  Free to get up there and try.  Some of the path is made up of stone stairways, some free rocks, and one metal stairway near the top.  

This hike can really play with your head.  It is more of a psychological game in many ways.  When you see how steep it is, it is hard to keep going.  I am retired and in decent shape and made it to the top in 30 minutes, 25 minutes on the way down.  I passed many on the way who said they wouldn’t go all the way.  Go early before the heat and the crowd.  

Know there are NO handrails so use your judgment about your capabilities to handle this hike. Many of the locals do it barefoot.  I saw a few of them even running up and down… A walking stick may be a good idea for many.

I did a lot of research to find out exactly the distance and elevation gain, and I can only find conflicting information (even from Strava and GPS).  The elevation gain is anywhere from 1450 to 1870 feet.  The average grade is 37%, not for the faint of heart.  I have read distances anywhere from 1.2 to 2 km.  

They suggest a time of 90 minutes to make it to the top where there is not that much to see.  For 55 pesos, you can walk on the ruins and around the top.  If you don’t want to pay that fee, you can have a look down towards town and up to the ruins without ‘touching’ them.  

I think, overall, it is more about the hike than the site, which is not extraordinary in any way.  

A few vendors of water, sodas, popsicles, are there for you along the way.

661345572.name: Be careful on the way down
661345572.author: a TripAdvisor user
661345572.reviewBody: I visited this site on a holiday when entry was free so there were A LOT of people there.  So many people there was a traffic jam on the way up (everyone had to stop and wait a couple of minutes until things got going again).  The pyramid itself is unremarkable.  I this this site is more about the journey than the destination. (The views are spectacular though).\n\nBe careful on the way down.  People are tired and in a hurry so there are more slips and tumbles on the way down.  Shiny rocks are slippery even when dry.

659069997.name: A Long Hike
659069997.author: a TripAdvisor user
659069997.reviewBody: This was quite a hike up and back.  If you are not in pretty good shape, I would suggest you avoid it.  The hike itself is over rock steps and takes about an hour plus each way,  I went on a Sunday, and it was quite crowded.  At the top is smallish pyramid and some nice views.\n\nI hurt the next day!

653578777.name: Crowded Trail
653578777.author: a TripAdvisor user
653578777.reviewBody: I was excited for this hike but didn\'t realize I\'d be doing it with all of Mexico. The trail was incredibly crowded and it was more like hiking up and down a staircase in a line of people. Be prepared - the trail goes straight up the mountain and if you have bad balance, vertigo, or health conditions you will struggle! And to me, unfortunately, the reward wasn\'t worth it - it\'s a small pyramid that\'s only impressive because of it\'s location.

652147000.name: Pre-Aztec Pyramid
652147000.author: a TripAdvisor user
652147000.reviewBody: The hike to this pyramid is very challenging, especially the descent so use hiking poles and wear appropriate attire including good walking or hiking shoes.  The elevation change is dramatic and not for the weak of heart.  The view at the pyramid is worth the effort.  Th descent is more difficult that the assent.  A plus is that the hike is shaded almost the entire time.  I would not recommend this hike if it is wet as the stones are very slippery.

651333550.name: Hike to a Small Pyramid
651333550.author: a TripAdvisor user
651333550.reviewBody: We came ill-prepared for our climb. There are two ways one though town about thirty minutes to the steps and one through a park a longer climb but not as steep. The later is a true hiking trail with one trail going to a lookout and the other to a pyramid,  We went through the park no vendors or food  I would suggest water, sunscreen, snack. There are no true pathways, in other words, no stone steps or pavement, and parts of the trail was washed out.  We took a guide with us.  I would recommend lightweight hiking boots as opposed to sneakers which can cause you to slide, The view is good but not recommended for those who do not feel comfortable climbing without handrails. We had a private guide which was great as he explained the history and beliefs of those who built the pyramids,

648840385.name: It\'s a great hike
648840385.author: a TripAdvisor user
648840385.reviewBody: Excellent hike and the location of the ruin is very impressive.  It has an awe-inspiring view of Tepoztlan.  Well worth the effort to get up there!

648503017.name: Nice but short climb
648503017.author: a TripAdvisor user
648503017.reviewBody: If you are in good shape, it\u2019s just a 30 minutes climb to the summit.  It\u2019s worth to pay the around $2.75 to get into te pyramid  at the summit. You can sit there are have a great view and rest there for a while.

647681247.name: Average hike - impressive views
647681247.author: a TripAdvisor user
647681247.reviewBody:
The hike up takes about an hour for a healthy person ... initially stone stairs, then more rocky. No views or attractions during the climb. The way is mostly shaded and other than avoiding trips and slips, climbing is not particularly difficult. Most people would still take short rests along the way to recover breath. The way down is easier, we did in 30’ non stop. We took water and sunblock with us but not much more needed. Please note that you can call it off and go back at any time if you feel the effort is too much.

When you get to the top, you need to pay about 3U$ to get to the pyramid. Views from there are really impressive and worth the effort. 

Other than the cashier at the top, I did not see any staff or guards ... so wonder what would happen if anything happens to you during the climb. Also no fences, handrails or signposts .... not a complaint, just an advice. These hiking trails do not normally have these safety features. 

There is a small parking lot (also about 3U$) close to the start, just one .. and gets easily full, so you are normally recommended to leave the car downtown and walk (about 30’ walk). But if you go on a week day off season, you might find a spot

You will find some artcrafts / food at the bottom ... good to get a water but not much more than that

647468967.name: A must!
647468967.author: a TripAdvisor user
647468967.reviewBody:
This magnificent experience is both, a physical challenge and a cultural experience.
You dont have to be in shape to be able to do the hike but it would surely help. There are 4 year olds who can do this, and all kinds of people, however, if you suffer from any physical problems such as knee pain you should avoid it since its about an hour and a half of climbing.
At the top you will see a small beautiful pyramid with an amazing view as well as herds of Coatis. A beautiful marsupial.
They will ask you for about $65 pesos at the top. Also they do sell drinks up there. 
No bathroom up there so take your precautions.

647060184.name: Tough climb, Excellent Views.
647060184.author: a TripAdvisor user
647060184.reviewBody: It takes about an hour to climb. Wear sturdy shoes because it is really rocky and steep. Most of the way up is shaded, but wear sunscreen. There are people on the top selling bottled water if you need it. It is a great workout and the views are stunning.

643999411.name: You can do it !
643999411.author: a TripAdvisor user
643999411.reviewBody:
My husband and I are 58 and 61 years old and in relatively good shape, we’re active.  However, even if you aren’t active you can make this climb!   Wear comfortable shoes, I wore running shoes, take water, wear a hat, sunscreen.  This is a fun and incredible experience.  The climb/trail is on stones of various sizes and shapes.  I actually found the climb easier than expected although it is strenuous.  

We made the climb up in less than an hour and less time on the descent.  It’s best to start early, before noon because it does get crowded.  

Enjoy!

643075040.name: A great mystical place to visit
643075040.author: a TripAdvisor user
643075040.reviewBody: You have everything: great food, interesting traditions, a beautiful mountain, a pyramid on the top and nature

634777108.name: Climbing to the heavens at Tepozteco
634777108.author: a TripAdvisor user
634777108.reviewBody:
On top of the mountain in the lovely town of Tepoztlan sit the ruins of Tepozteco, a temple to the god of the ancient Mexican drink pulque. The view is extraordinary, both to the colorful town below and of the sun-filled blue sky above. Standing atop the small temple, above the world and with majestic black birds circling overhead, you can understand why this space was considered holy and close to the heavens.

All that said, these are sights you need to earn to see and the hour-long, almost vertical trek up makes you pay fully for them. Prepare yourself with the following:

* water
* something energy-filled to snack on
* a device to take pictures
* shoes that are both comfortable and that you can hike with
* 55 pesos for the entrance fee
* an abundance of patience

Following a straight line from the historic center of town's main road, you basically walk to the foot of the mountain and then climb up. And up and up. As you ascend from the road to the foot of the mountain, you'll pass through a market which will be both your last chance to use the restroom and get water for the next hour of so. And you will need plenty of water to do this hike.

The way up is delineated by a stone path which at best are actual steps but for the majority of the hike are stones which sort of suggest a pathway. It can be hard on the knees and you can feel going up in your whole body as you try to pick out which is the best stone to step on next. The pathway is thankfully shaded by jungle trees, so you may be exhausted but at least you're not being roasted by the sun as you climb.

This is a hike that can test your resolve, or at least it tested mine. You feel like you keep climbing but the top never comes; there are only more stones ahead. But if you persevere, and take as many rest stops as you need, you'll eventually be clear of the trees. The top will be closer, but there'll still be more stone steps then a metal ladder going up and then even more stone steps and then you're there: at the small rest area before the ticket table/tent where you can catch your breath along with everyone else who made the hike. (And take a moment to consider the people who work there who have to trek up and down every day)

Tickets as of November 2018 are 55 pesos, and you can choose not to purchase one if you're just there for the view. But if you've just spent an hour climbing straight up, scrambling up stones through a jungle, you might as well see the temple.

The temple Tepozteco itself is small compared to what you can find in other areas, and time and history have stripped it down to its most basic structure. But the view is stunning and a well-earned reward for your hard work up. 

Remember going down is as vertical as going up, so take your time again. The market you passed on your way up will now be a welcome place to get some food and a drink (or two), though you can also find more formal places to refuel as you walk back to town.

Tepoztlan is about an hour away from Mexico City and can be reached by bus from Tasquena/Autobuses del Sur. A number of bus lines go to Tepoztlan on the way to another stop. From the tiny Tepoztlan bus station you can catch a taxi into town. Total transportation costs for me as of November 2018 were:

* 10 pesos to/from Tasquena on the 2 metro line
* 269 pesos roundtrip bus to/from Tepoztlan
* 40 pesos taxi to town from bus station
* 35 pesos taxi back to bus station

This, plus the temple entrance fee, comes to about $22 USD. Well-worth it for the view from the heavens above.

634467893.name: Rigorous Hike
634467893.author: a TripAdvisor user
634467893.reviewBody: This is a beautiful, if strenuous hike.  The story of the leader who was a legend in his own right and then converted to Christianity is endearing.  The temple is lovely, but the highlight is the trip up (very up) the canyon to the top of the cliff where the temple is.  Walking sticks were a big help.  At least 1 hour hike up and 45 minutes down.

633882036.name: the great tepozteco
633882036.author: a TripAdvisor user
633882036.reviewBody: I went there with my family and the only thing I can say is that it is incredible, when you get to the top you can see an incredible view.

631094188.name: Totally worth the effort
631094188.author: a TripAdvisor user
631094188.reviewBody:
It’s a grind getting up here, and even more brutal getting back down, but totally worth it! This was my third trip up and hopefully not my last. The views at the top are incredible, but the way up is pretty awesome as well. The trail is more steps than a trail, and goes up a steep canyon with beautiful vegetation and rock formations. There are some views along the way but it’s really when you get to the top that you are rewarded for your efforts with huge views of the valley and town below. 

We paid to access the pyramid and natural area. We ate lunch in the natural area side and nearly had it stolen by some very habituated Coatis. Cute but rather aggressive and a bit of a nuisance while trying to eat your lunch.
